In 1981, Salim Ahmed Salim
In 1996, Salim was again mentioned for the office.

At the continental level, following the invitation of the President of the African Development Bank, he has since March, 2002 been acting as African Water Ambassador whose responsibilities include advocacy, sensitization, and mobilization of support on African water issues.
Salim is also Chair of the Foundation’s Ibrahim Prize Committee, having taken over from the inaugural chair, Kofi Annan in 2011.

Salim was born in what was then the Sultanate of Zanzibar
an ethnic Arab of Omani descent
local-born mixed-descent Tanzanian
Tanzanian politician and diplomat
in Zanzibar and later pursued his undergraduate studies at the St. Stephen's College of the University of Delhi
He became a student activist in the 1950s and was founder and first Vice President of the All-Zanzibar Student Union.
Chief editor of a Zanzibar daily paper, Secretary General of the All-Zanzibar Journalists Organisation 1963–1964
and obtained his master's degree in International Affairs from the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia University in New York.
Deputy chief representative of the Zanzibar Office based in Havana, Cuba 1961–1962
Tanzania Ambassador to the Arab Republic of Egypt 1964–1965
Tanzanian High Commissioner (i.e. Ambassador) to India 1965–1968
Tanzania Ambassador to the People’s Republic of China 1969–1970
June/July 1972: Chairman of the United Nations Special Mission to Niue
August 1972: Drafting Committee of the Political Committee of the Ministerial Conference of non-Aligned States, Georgetown, Guyana
April 1973: Chairman of the Political Committee of International Conference of Experts in Support of the Victims of Colonialism and Apartheid in Southern Africa, Oslo
1975: Chairman of the Security Council's Committee on Sanctions against Southern Rhodesia
1981: President of the International Conference on Sanctions against South Africa.
1984: President of the Paris International Conference Against Apartheid.
Kurt Waldheim of Austria
He could also count on China to veto Waldheim in the Security Council.
However, Salim was opposed by the Reagan administration in the United States
which regarded him as an anti-American radical who was hostile to South Africa
Chairman, Advisory Board, Institute of Security Studies (ISS) based in Pretoria, South Africa
and supported Palestinian statehood
The Soviet Union also opposed Salim for his activism and his pro-China stance.

In 1996, Salim was again mentioned for the office.

At the continental level, following the invitation of the President of the African Development Bank, he has since March, 2002 been acting as African Water Ambassador whose responsibilities include advocacy, sensitization, and mobilization of support on African water issues.

He could also count on China to veto Waldheim in the Security Council.
However, Salim was opposed by the Reagan administration in the United States
which regarded him as an anti-American radical who was hostile to South Africa
Chairman, Advisory Board, Institute of Security Studies (ISS) based in Pretoria, South Africa
and supported Palestinian statehood
The Soviet Union also opposed Salim for his activism and his pro-China stance.
